719194f-a.text:
Convent Ave. (running today between the house and trees) at West 143rd Street, showing the Alexander Hamilton home (Hamilton Grange) and the thirteen commemorative trees. The house has been moved to a new location and adjoins St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church at the N.E. corner of Convent Ave. and West 141st Street. The trees stand upon
what is today the S.E. corner of West 143rd Street.
About 1888.
Wurts Brothers.

719195f-a.text:
Convent Ave. at West 143rd Street, showing a row of 4-story structures on the Avenue and Alexander Hamilton's famous thirteen trees at what would be today (1937) the S.W. corner of the aforementioned intersection. The last of these symbols of the thirteen original states was cut down in 1908 and a portion of the trunk retained by Hamilton Grange; the former residence of this heroic individual, which originally stood to the rear of the same. Photographer is viewing eastward from a point east of Amsterdam Ave. and north of West 142nd Street. For further information see: New York, Old and New by Rufus Rockwell Wilson, Illustration facing page 326.
1891.
Gift of Randall Comfort.
Neg. 2823
